explanation: To determine whether OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl calls itself (directly or indirectly) you must inspect all functions/macros it invokes and any symbols those may reference that could form a cycle back to the target. 1) OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — this is the direct callee recorded in the static call graph; its implementation must be checked to ensure it does not (directly or via other callees) call OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl. 2) OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — the macro used in the function that expands to the actual table lookup (it may call or expand to OS_ObjectIndexFromToken or other helpers); inspect the macro expansion to see if it introduces further calls. 3) OS_impl_count_sem_table — the object/table symbol passed to the macro; its definition may influence macro expansion or auxiliary helpers used in the lookup (e.g., function pointers), so inspect it for calls that could lead back to the target. 4) sem_getvalue — the POSIX semaphore call used here; confirm its implementation (or documentation) does not invoke any application callbacks that could produce an indirect recursion to OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl. 5) OS_CountSemGetInfo — the public wrapper/caller recorded in the call graph; inspect it to ensure there is no path from top-level callers through OS_CountSemGetInfo back into OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl (i.e., check for mutual recursion via the wrapper). Checking these symbols is sufficient to establish whether any call chain starting in OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl can return to it, which is required to verify compliance with the MISRA rule forbidding direct or indirect self-calls.
